comments.commentBody: Actually a combination of roots (turnips, carrots, parsnips, tiny onions & shallots, rutabagas seasoned with a bit of salt, pepper, garlic powder, dried parsley, pinch of sugar, fresh orange zest)! I use this combo with my roast chickens and roast turkey quite often. I tend to do more hard fruits with my ducks!!!
Go with fruit oriented accompaniments, as Sifton suggests: cranberry, apple or orange all work.  Another idea: substitute apples of your choosing for the potatoes.

Absolutely agree that a work guarantee program is what all modern economies should implement to utilise unused resources.

Here is a good article on Kelton's ideas for Bernie Sanders to implement one day hopefully: http://declass3.com/2015/09/18/this-bernie-sanders-appointee-has-propose...

It would be a huge automatic stabiliser that would allow the economy to largely self correct and not have such major booms and busts.

There is plenty of research already done to model the effects of policies like this we just need the political will.

Paul has a history of misreading Spanish elections;

On May 25th, he wrote

"We just had another electoral earthquake in the euro area: Podemos-backed candidates have won local elections in Madrid and Barcelona....Very Serious Europeans were hailing Spain as a great success story, a vindication of the whole program. Evidently the Spanish people don’t agree. "

Reading this, Gareth Cyprus, wrote this comment:

"Your ideas of electoral earthquakes are somewhat strange.

.. For example, here is the CIS poll published in El Pais on 4th February: Popular Party 27%, Socialists 22%, Podemos 24%, Citizens 3%. Yesterday, it was difficult to discern the Podemos vote, because it merged into so many local rainbow coalitions, but it probably managed around 11-12%. The Popular Party took 27%, Socialists 25%, and Citizens 6-8%.

In Madrid, the Popular Party took 33%, Socialists 25%, Podemos and friends 18% and Citizens 12%. Some earthquake.

In Barcelona, in the town, Podemos and friends beat the Catalan nationalists 25% to 23%. Crushing, what? They owed this success to the intelligent policy of simultaneously being against independence for regions, but in favour of allowing regions to hold referenda on independence. ..All in all, this was a strong comeback by the traditional parties, Popular Party and the Socialists, modest success or something a tad better by Podemos, and a good try by Citizens."

The Cis poll then is similar to today' vote. save that Podemos lost supporters
You can skip vinegar; I did--fine.

Dr. K,

Spain is not a success story. What is so unusual and worth of investigation is why the defenders of austerity is defining success as 21% unemployment. I suspect the very well off elites think they have it made, but the unemployed who are traveling through out Europe to get work are not happy. With unemployment this high for such a long time, most historians agree that the society begins to rot from within. In a recent conversation with a visitor from Spain, I learned from her that government business is not as accessible to the citizens as it is here in the US.

The World is in a slump now and I suspect it will only get worse. Austerity has very little to do with improving the quality of life of a people. Spain needs markets and jobs. And greater investment in goods that can be broadly shared. All that I see happening in Spain is decreasing wages and unemployment and a lot of brain drain.
The governor of Michigan just voiding local elections may go on the biggest social injustice list. How is that Constitutional?

The water crisis in Flint, Michigan has to a prime example. I was only vaguely aware of it until its severity hit home when I saw a report by Rachel Maddow.

This truly is social injustice, both those words carrying deep meaning.
Socially, Flint was a failure, not of government, but of those who supposedly govern. Flint had the kind of money problems common in many rustbelt cities undermined by the export of jobs. Michigan’s solution was to appoint an emergency administrator to rule, not govern. To save money, he decided Flint would abandon Detroit’s water system and use water from the Flint River. With no anti-corrosion system, the water supply was degraded by lead leached from the water pipes.

The effect of lead on the human body, especially of a small child, is well known. The alarm was raised, but it was months before the authorities acknowledged the problem and eventually restored Detroit city water. This was only a partial fix; the newly leached plumbing had been stripped of protective organic matter and remains a source of lead. Long lasting as the damage is to physical infrastructure, it’s irreversible for people who have been harmed. That’s injustice of the first magnitude. Flint has emerged from one-person rule. But nobody is being held civilly, politically or criminally responsible. Not the emergency manager and not those who foisted autocracy on the community. And not those who profit by shipping out whole communities’ livelihoods.

As others have indicated, this recipe is a good springboard for adaptations.  I added a pound of browned Italian sausage and some sliced mushrooms, as well as some extra cheese.  I'd like more olives, but my family is not so nuts about them.  But they did not complain as this is written.  They mostly just add a great flavor.  The gruyere was a welcome taste surprise.  Yummy!  Also, I used a 28 oz. can of Cento crushed tomatoes, saving myself the need to clean a blender or food processor.
Tristan, didn't get a chance yesterday to say I'm glad BODE is doing WELL. Nice to see him sans blue collar.
Thank you, arcoiris. I called Bode my flower child since he looked like a morning glory with his head poking out of the dreaded cone.

I guess I missed the health update yesterday, Tristan.

So glad that your darling is feeling better and is no longer having to wear the Cone of Shame.

Very fetching emu and a fun puzzle.

It doesn't seem like I hear many of these expressions any more but I certainly hear my father's voice in them. His standards were "whosit" and "doohicky" and WATCHAMACALLIT was definitely part of his vernacular.

I believe it's only dirty in the sense of "Dirty DINGUS Magee." I'd use him as an avatar, but he would look too much like Frank Sinatra.

Even the often crude Urban Dictionary definition appears to be within standards,

http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=dingus
Thanks for mentioning that coconut cream works.  I would love to use regular cream but am lactose intolerant and suffer when I go ahead with cream, which I sometimes do because I love it in recipes!
Certainly no one here.  Been that way for 40 years.
I used a mix of cranberries and 500 grams of apples and reduced sugar to 1/4 cup.  Tart but good.

After reading the comments of Honeybee and mm, I think my query stands clarified. Honeybee has presented one version and mm has explained the step relationship in a different way. I feel both are right in their own way. However mm has clearly explained that even some step - parents are great though not everyone is a good parent as in the case of biological parents.

I understand clearly now that all good parents, doesn't matter biological or step - parents, will surely bring up all children in a very caring and affectionate way and that there won't be any problem regarding the understanding between the siblings.

My dad married my stepmother when I was 17 and in college (and my much older stepsiblings were long out of the house), about 20 years ago. While my stepmother is a lovely person, I don't consider her to be my parent -- or family, really. Ditto for her (awful) kids and the rest of her (mostly certifiable) family.
Katie : Your comment and that of Honeybee synchronises with that of Indian sentiment in general regarding the step relationship.

Teri Carter is a good writer. It's nice that the children have accepted her as their mother though it took sometime. In the event of the couple deciding to have a child of their own, then perhaps priorities of the writer might change or might not change depending upon her personality.

I am more interested to know from our learned readers, who might be having such relationship, how the step - parent has maintained the relationship with all the children and how the children interacted among themselves and whether their relationship with their step - parent is same or changed given the new development.

So do you agree with Stephanie Kelton, Bernie's economic advisor, that the federal government should guarantee a decent federal job to all those who need one or paid training for such a job? They could fix roads and bridges, help teach small classes, etc.. This would allow the government to eliminate most present forms of welfare.
john - Emphasis on the ' sub ' portion of subsistence :(

But that would be the end of cheap labour and, therefore, the redistribution of the results of the enormous productivity growth of the last decades. Totally unfair to the current owners of everything.

James Jordan,

Your point about the defenders of austerity claim of success when there is 21 percent unemployment deserving investigating is spot on.

After reading the paper by Rosnick and Weisbrot, the concept of a reserve army of labor (see Marx and Engels) jumped out at me. Consequently, "labor reforms" demanded by the purveyors of austerity in Europe and the United States seem to mean using high levels of unemployment and underemployment -- the reserve army of labor -- to ensure wages are kept at an extremely low level. Without government intervention to improve labor conditions, eventually wages will drop to subsistence levels.
I'm glad you and I are on the same side, Richard.

This discussion harkens back to "Bloomberg View"'s article on this subject in July of this year. Leonid Bershidsky, makes the case that Spain, and Ireland, make a case for austerity, not against it, but does so with some equivocation. Bershidsky, writing out of Berlin, uses the article as a soapbox to defend Germany's case for European austerity.

http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2015-07-31/two-points-for-austerit...

I'm inclined to discount "Bloomberg View"'s article. London School of Economics posted this in November.

http://www.lse.ac.uk/publicEvents/pdf/2015-ST/20151117-Transcript-Debt-a...

While about Ireland, not Spain, the similarities may justify considering the paper's data, premises and conclusions in regard to both. Patrick Honohan, the paper's author, is Governor of the Central Bank of Ireland and arguably qualified in this matter. But I'm no economist and defer to Krugman level thinking to decide that matter.

Some commenters have noted that if austerity is so bad why haven't voters "clearly" punished government. I propose that doesn't decide the matter either. It is possible, in Spain and Ireland, that a form of "Stockholm syndrome" formed between peoples threatened with fiscal, social and cultural catastrophe, and their governments leading to many defending austerity, regardless of the burden, duration and outcome.

As with The Great Depression we may not clearly know for decades.
.

This was excellent.  Based upon some of the other comments, I substituted cream for some of the broth and really mashed the eggplant through the strainer for quite awhile to extract as much eggplant yumminess as possible.  Used more than a pinch of hot ground pepper and lots of za'atar.  It was delicious!  My husband said it was the best soup I'd ever made.

You're right, Amitai, but I think the clue is okay because it doesn't use a time reference. It doesn't say "now." It could refer to a Gaza group from any time.

Alas, that first paragraph should have been deleted.
But my point still stands.

The problem is somewhere else. Bernanke in a lucid moment said it well. "Debt" and "austerity" become very limited explanatory memes. The rate of return is low for historical standards despite their applications. Neither QE nor austerity work very well in the complex whole of the "economy." As demonstrated they are only partial and ineffective solutions.

“The state of the economy, not the Fed, is the ultimate determinant of the sustainable level of real returns. This helps explain why real interest rates are low throughout the industrialized world, not just in the United States.”

1. We need money to conduct commerce.

2. As the economy grows it needs more and more money.

3. Money comes from the federal government via the FED,

4. The way money gets from the federal government to us is by federal spending.

5. The deficit measure the net flow of money from the federal government to people, businesses, and state & local governments.

6. The debt is the net accumulation of this money over time.

7. Too high debt or deficits have never hurt our economy while surpluses for a while have always done so.

The federal government has balanced the budget, eliminated deficits for more than three years in just six periods since 1776, during 1817-21, 1823-36, 1852-57, 1867-73, 1880-93, and 1920-30. The debt was paid down 29%. 100%, 59%, 27%, 57%, and 38% respectively. A depression began in 1819, 1837, 1857, 1873, 1893 and 1929.

8. As a percentage of GDP our public debt was about 50% higher in 1946. The period 1946 - 1973 was a period sometimes called the Great Prosperity during which real median household income surged 74%. In fact we INCREASED the debt in dollars by 75% during this period. What happened was as the economy grew, the debt became insignificant.

After WWI, we DECREASED the debt by 38% by 1929. Then what happened?

9. Ideas that may be appropriate for your personal finances do not apply to the finances of a huge country that lasts a long time, that can print as much money as it needs, and whose debt is in it's own currency.

Trog,

Check Andrew Zimmerman's cogent (and factually correct) comment re Spain's economy.

I assume Dr. Krugman will also point to the happy times in Puerto Rico, Venezuela, and Greece as further evidence that unrestrained deficit spending is the only path to prosperity.

In truth, once a country has spent far beyond its means, neither austerity nor traditional expansionary fiscal policies will rescue it. There is no painless solution. Probably the least bad would be default, devaluation, and expulsion from the credit markets.

Until the basic laws of economics come back into political vogue, I look forward to watching the indebted, stagnant Eurozone economies try to borrow their way to prosperity.
